title: Event Planner Guide: Selling Unused Client Gifts and Bottles
metaTitle: Event Planners: How to Sell Unused Alcohol | Proof Cellars
metaDescription: Events often have leftover alcohol budget or unused bottles. Learn how event planners can liquidate stock for clients or agencies.
summary: A simple workflow to inventory, photograph, and submit bottles quickly and discreetly.

sections.heading: Quick Answer
content: Weddings, galas, and corporate retreats often over-order. Once the event is over, returning alcohol to distributors is often legally impossible.
list: We buy leftover sealed cases and loose bottles.

sections.heading: Post-Event Liquidation
list: Immediately after the event, inventory what is left.
Separate opened bottles (kitchen/staff use) from sealed bottles (sellable).
Keep them out of hot venues or loading docks.

sections.heading: Client vs Agency Ownership
list: Client Owned: If the client paid for the booze, the proceeds go to them. We can pay the client directly.
Agency Owned: If you bundled it into a fee, you might own it. Check your contract.
We need to know who the legal seller is.

sections.heading: Logistics
content: Don't haul it back to the office if you don't have to.
list: We can sometimes arrange pickup directly from the venue loading dock if scheduled in advance.
Otherwise, use our shipping labels to send it from the venue's mailroom.

sections.heading: Common Mistakes
list: Leaving cases at the venue 'for the staff' (throwing away thousands of dollars).
Letting it bake in a truck over the weekend.
Mixing up empty display bottles with real ones.

sections.heading: What to Do Next
list: Take a photo of the pallet/stack.

faqs.question: What about open bar leftovers?
faqs.answer: If the bottle is open, it's worthless. If the seal is intact, we buy it.

faqs.question: Can I sell it on behalf of a bride/groom?
faqs.answer: Yes, with their permission. A simple email confirmation works.

faqs.question: Do you buy vodka/gin?
faqs.answer: We focus on high-end Whiskey, Tequila, and Cognac. Standard well spirits (Titos, Bacardi) have little resale value.
